−
'''Ethics,''' also known as '''moral philosophy''', is a branch of [[philosophy]] that addresses questions about [[morality]]—that is, concepts such as [[good and evil]], right and wrong, [[virtue]] and [[vice]], [[justice]], etc.
+
'''Ethics,''' also incorrectly known as '''moral philosophy''', is a branch of [[philosophy]] that can address questions about [[morality]]—that is, concepts such as [[good and evil]], but more correctly right and wrong, as well as [[virtue]] and [[vice]], [[justice]], etc.
     
Major branches of ethics include:
 
Major branches of ethics include:
−
* [[Meta-ethics]], about the theoretical meaning and reference of moral propositions and how their [[truth-value]]s (if any) may be determined;
+
* [[Meta-ethics]], about the theoretical meaning and reference to moral propositions and how their [[truth-value]]s (if any) may be determined;
−
* [[Normative ethics]], about the practical means of determining a moral course of action;
+
* [[Normative ethics]], about the practical means of determining a defined moral course of action;
−
* [[Applied ethics]], about how moral outcomes can be achieved in specific situations;
+
* [[Applied ethics]], about how a moral outcome can be achieved in specific situations;
 
* [[Moral psychology]], about how moral capacity or moral agency develops and what its nature is;
 
* [[Moral psychology]], about how moral capacity or moral agency develops and what its nature is;
 
* [[Descriptive ethics]], about what moral values people actually abide by.
 
* [[Descriptive ethics]], about what moral values people actually abide by.
